component:ember-data-autocomplete-js/pod.title: Autocomplete
component:ember-data-autocomplete-js/pod.text: This {{autocomplete}} component is a textbox powered by autocomplete.js and Ember Data's store in fetching type ahead completion results that your user can choose.

attributes.name: Autocomplete
attributes.description: This {{autocomplete}} component is a textbox powered by autocomplete.js and Ember Data's store in fetching type ahead completion results that your user can choose.

fields.name: globalOptions
fields.description: The globalOptions for the autocomplete initialization. TODO: should these be merge-able?

fields.name: _autocompleteInstance
fields.description: The Autocomplete instance that is created on #didInsertElement.

methods.name: autocompleted
methods.description: Triggered when the query is autocompleted. Autocompleted means the query was changed to the hint. The event handler will be invoked with 3 arguments: the jQuery event object, the suggestion object, and the name of the dataset the suggestion belongs to.

methods.name: closed
methods.description: Triggered when the dropdown menu of the autocomplete is closed.

methods.name: cursorChanged
methods.description: Triggered when the dropdown menu cursor is moved to a different suggestion. The event handler will be invoked with 3 arguments: the jQuery event object, the suggestion object, and the name of the dataset the suggestion belongs to.

methods.name: cursorRemoved
methods.description: Triggered when the cursor leaves the selections or its current index is lower than 0.

methods.name: empty
methods.description: Triggered when all datasets are empty.

methods.name: opened
methods.description: Triggered when the dropdown menu of the autocomplete is opened.

methods.name: redrawn
methods.description: Triggered when appendTo is used and the wrapper is resized/repositionned.

methods.name: selected
methods.description: Triggered when a suggestion from the dropdown menu is selected. The event handler will be invoked with the following arguments: the jQuery event object, the suggestion object, the name of the dataset the suggestion belongs to and a context object. The context contains a .selectionMethod key that can be either click, enterKey, tabKey or blur, depending how the suggestion was selected.

methods.name: shown
methods.description: Triggered when the dropdown menu of the autocomplete is shown (opened and non-empty).

methods.name: updated
methods.description: Triggered when a dataset is rendered.

methods.name: willDestroy
methods.description: Destroy the #_autocompleteInstance instance that was created during #didInsertElement.

accessors.name: _selector
accessors.description: The html #id selector of this component used to instantiate the Autocomplete instance.

arguments.name: include
arguments.description: The comma separated list of dasherized relationship names that should be side-loaded (included) in the JSONAPI payload response.

arguments.name: modelName
arguments.description: The name of the Ember Data model that will be used by the store.

arguments.name: sort
arguments.description: What sort criteria do you want to pass to the store's query?

template:docs/how-it-works.title: How It Works
template:docs/how-it-works.text: How It Works These examples demonstrate component invocation using Angle Brackets and named arguments syntax (`@`). We use the Ember Data store and JSON-API semantics to search for your model results. User Model Let's say in your Ember Data world you have a User model. import DS from 'ember-data'; import { attr } from '@ember-decorators/data'; import { computed } from '@ember-decorators/object' const { Model } = DS; export default class UserModel extends Model { /** Attributes ------------------------------------------------- / @attr('boolean') active; @attr('date') dateOfBirth; @attr('string') email; @attr('string') firstName; @attr('string') lastName; /* Computed ------------------------------------------------- */ @computed('firstName', 'lastName') fullName() { return ${this.firstName} ${this.lastName}; } } Autocomplete Component Perhaps you want to choose a user from an autocomplete text box, below is an example of the component you'd invoke from your template. Autocomplete @displayKey="fullName" @filter="by_name_search" @modelName="user" @selected=(action "onSelected") @sort="last-name,first-name" The <Autocomplete> component extends @ember/component/text-field and you're delivered an <input> element that is wrapped with Algolia's autocomplete after it is inserted into the DOM. Why do you care that it's an input element? Simply because you might want to style it. Should you be using Bootstrap you could add class="form-control" to get some style love. Responding To A Chosen Option You need to bind an action to the @selected attribute which is responsible for doing something with the User instance that is chosen from the autocomplete input. Below is an example of what a typical action will look like. import { action } from '@ember-decorators/object' import Controller from '@ember/controller'; export default class IndexController extends Controller { @action onSelected(event, user, dataset, context) { // do something with the chosen user parameter alert(user.dateOfBirth.toISOString()); return true; } } Autocomplete Component's Use Of The Store So what happened to populate the autocomplete options? Effectively, the Ember Data store was called upon to perform a loadRecords (basically an Ember Data query). // ... const textboxValue = this.value; // whatever the user typed const modelName = this.modelName; // => "user" - the @modelName value you passed into the component const filter = this.filter; // => "by_name_search" the @filter value you passed into the component const include = this.include; // => "" the @include value you passed into the component const sort = this.sort; // => "last-name,first-name" the @sort value you passed into the component this.store.loadRecords(modelName { filter: { this.filter: textboxValue }, include: this.include, sort: this.sort }) // ...

template:docs/index.title: Installation
template:docs/index.text: Installation Install Or Upgrade ember install ember-data-autocomplete-js What Happens ember-data-autocomplete-js is downloaded and added to your project. Algolia's autocomplete.js npm package is installed and imported globally. ember-data is installed or upgraded. If you don't want the upgrade make sure to edit your package.json devDependencies rolling back the new ember-data version number. ember-data-storefront is installed because we use the loadRecords method that to perform queries on your model.

template:docs/quickstart.title: Quickstart
template:docs/quickstart.text: Quickstart Let's say in your Ember Data world you have a User model. We'll use JSON-API semantics to search your users through Ember Data's store and then render them in the autocomplete control. Below is an example of a template. And below is an example of the controller's action that raises an alert containing a message about the user that was chosen from the autocomplete.js text input. // ... @action onSelected(event, user/, dataset, context/) { alert(You chose ${user.firstName}!!!); return true; } // ...

template:index/index-content.title: Motivation
template:index/index-content.text: Motivation Looking for the quickstart? . When we started using Ember back in 2014 Twitter's Typeahead component was quite popular and we incorporated it into our application. Since it's been abandoned Algolia has forked the project at autocomplete.js. This Ember addon wraps the typeahead/autocomplete functionality in a relatively convenient component and uses Ember Data to search your models. Discover An Issue? Search and raise
